So this was an interesting one. In many cases, a review now on this game may seem inconsequential. It's by no means a new product anymore, and largely forgotten in the scheme of FPS games however felt apt to play through during a global pandemic.

Simply, this is a fine game. Nothing groundbreaking, no unique hook, and thematically similar to many titles which have come out before it. Ignoring early technical issues on its release, which for those who remember was strangely reminiscent of the original game in the franchise (though for different reasons), this is a game well executed. It had a goal in mind and met it. Visually, on a current medium tier PC it still looks and sounds great. The overall picture the player has of the game, particularly in the open world is complex, surprisingly dense, and clearly laboured over by talented people. As with many games that play on this scale, close scrutiny of details will start to reveal the necessary drop in fidelity in order to achieve the overall outcome. During gameplay however, this was no issue, and certainly nothing that would diminish the players immersion.

In terms of mechanics, the game feels polished. The movement is good and the gunplay matches it, giving the player confidence that they are in control at all times. The weapons and abilities themselves are not lacking and provide a good sense of feedback, even if it does feel at times generic. The one criticism here, which perhaps applies more to keyboard+mouse control, is the need to tap a separate button to dash. I'm far more familiar and comfortable with a double-tap in any direction. This however would be the only criticism in terms of how the game feels.

The story is serviceable, however feels to be the weakest point in the game. To be fair to the developers, providing a compelling story with engaging characters, balanced against a large open world that has to offer an extended game time (I'm over 20 hours now and have yet to open ever ark, there's still plenty left to do), is a difficult tightrope to walk. An admirable effort has been made here, and the degree of audio dialogue, location backstory and unique factions is impressive. However the core actors of this story do not leave a lasting impression, and as the game progresses the exchanges with these characters feel odd compared to its earlier moments, where the humour of the dialogue was pushed beyond what could be sustained over its entirety. For all it's issues, the original Rage managed to conjure a greater sense of threat and urgency with regards to the Authority. In this iteration, they are less an oppressive wall of force to be feared than a group relegated to staged boss arenas. A shame, given how well this game hangs together overall.

The real draw with Rage 2 is in the open world exploration, and the almost cathartic feel it has. It's almost therapeutic at times to simple travel out to the varied zones of the world map and clear them out. The game is at its best here; all the tools and mechanics at your disposal, and your own desire to push as deep as you care to in your exploration. All in all a well crafted game, easily worth a go for any FPS fan, especially if you simply want to explore the world. Just don't expect to remember any of the characters once you're done.

It's easy to replicate the complete, unrecoverable game freeze - have V-sync on, press Tab, use your mouse to click the Vehicle options, and try and click on the Phoenix to upgrade it. BOOM. Total, unrecoverable game freeze that forces you to use the task manager to close the program out (not even alt-f4 closes it!)

There is a work around if you do decide to play - turn off V-sync. Sadly for me, I was right on the edge of 60 FPS at 4K, so V-sync was a must have feature to reduce the horrible screen tearing - hence why I cannot recommend a game that the game developers don't care enough to fix with a bug this bad.

[h1]Предисловие:[/h1]
Первая RAGE была высокомерной, но не во всем удавшейся игрой, получившей, тем не менее, своих поклонников. У меня же была причина купить RAGE 2, ведь я давно слежу за разработчиками из Avalanche Studios, которые создали Just Cause и всегда умудрялись показывать какой-то прогресс. [h1]Сюжет:[/h1]
Игра начинается с выбора персонажа, выбор которого ни на что не виляет. RAGE 2 полностью следует правилам Джона Кармака, создателя первой игры, который говорил, что сюжет в играх вообще не нужен и не важен и с этим я абсолютно не согласен. Начну сразу с минусов игры, и поверьте, их много. To add some substance to my review about the game itself, rather than DRM related or publisher related beef. For reference, I started my playthrough on the maximum available difficulty. The setting of the game is beautiful, I will admit. Grand vistas, pretty shanty towns, I think they used color well. The wasteland feels like a living wasteland.

[b]Difficulty and AI[/b]
Difficulty seems to only chonk up the armor, damage, frequency of chippable armor pieces existing on fodder enemies. I think it also affects their aim to a degree. I had to turn down my difficulty due to 3 main problems. 

Approaching and infiltrating/assaulting an enemy base would lose too much HP from any distance.
With no way to recover or protect your health this becomes a very slow fight uphill where you just sit behind a wall while the AI either surrounds you and overwhelms you or worse, they just sit behind cover huckin' grenades and rockets at you until you finally give.

That's two problems in one, you get very few tools for breathing room or health recovery. You also have very few ways to protect yourself. [i]At the start of the game[/i]

My third problem, this game seems to be tuned like a typical Bethesda game, Fallout 4, TES:IV Oblivion come to mind. It seems you're expected to start the game on or below Normal until you unlock more guns, more gun upgrades, and more powers.

By the halfway mark of the game I had to crank my difficulty back up to max because it was too easy, too boring. Even at max difficulty it felt too easy because of the Power combos/rotation I will talk about later.

[b]The Tutorial: Where am I, what is shooting me[/b]
The game plops you into the fray in the tutorial. First you select male or female protagonist(this doesn't effect gameplay in any way), I appreciate the choice. 
You are immediately sent into the fray, given a gun and some live targets to learn the game against. Smoke screens everywhere, explosions, grenades, flying projectiles, and it seems that every enemy AI is more aware of you than they are of your horde of AI comrades.

The controls aren't really problematic, the aiming is comfortable, the guns feel good and they have decent impact. 

The main problem here is information overflow. They spam you with popups that freeze the game and interrupt your train of thought while you are moving into cover from the onslaught of grenades, rockets and assault rifles getting thrown at you. This also stops your movement momentum.
Most of my deaths in the tutorial were from sprinting to cover, getting a popup, then trying to sprint to cover as soon as my popup closes. 


[b]Guns: lots of guns, not a bad start.[/b]
The good: they shoot good, they sound good, they look good.

The bad: enemy AI is mostly not projectiles from my memory, and when they are projectiles, there is an aggressive firing squad lined up to pop your melon. Their accuracy and deviance, control of their weapons, it's all too much for me. I've had plenty fun on Nightmare in Doom 2016, and Doom Eternal. Hordes and projectiles aren't a huge problem for me as long as I can feasibly game them to avoid them.

[b]Powers[/b] 
A lot of powers that feel natural to use and chain together, sometimes it feels like you're some kind of hack and slash badass.
The good: they look, feel and sound good in a lot of ways. Impact, ragdolls, mobility, it kind of feels like Doomfist on drugs.

The bad: it feels forceful in a similar way to Doom Eternal's rock-paper-shotgun, you're almost expected to use your mobility attacks in a specific pattern that feels more like an MMORPG rotation than a shooter with utilities. 
This is probably more my own hangup than the game's 'cause what I want from this is OP utilities for powers, if I get to have a super punch, I want to be Saitama. If I get to have superhero landing groundslams, I want it to shatter the earth. Visually, it does, and there's a knockdown effect, but it does little damage.

[b]Story: There is one[/b]
The good: I remember liking the acting and voice actors, I remember feeling invested in the story.

The bad: Open world. It's another open world game, I was craving this kind of game when I bought it and it delivered in spades. Unfortunately they stop feeling unique, they stop feeling interesting. It's a big empty world with pockets of instances where you rinse-repeat your way through hordes.

TLDR: 4.5/10 game, maybe even 4/10, those scores are being generous as well, I have a soft spot for id software due to childhood enjoyment of things like DOOM and DOOM2, that, and the fact that I have a striking suspicion Bethesda as a publisher had something to do with how much of a disaster this game was, be it time restraints on the developers or lack of budget, etc. However, there's also the case that Avalanche Studios also worked on this, and their touch is definitely felt throughout the game world, I'll get to that later. I do not know who did more, id or Avalanche (I do have a striking suspicion, however.)
Played on Hard mode for reference, couldn't even bother to bring myself to play the DLC once I beat the game. I'm going to do most of this review in bullet point style for convenience sake, both for myself and for you.

Pros:
1. Good shotgun, it's partially an id game, they're pretty good at making those.
2. Good movement, I wouldn't call it anything to write home about, but it's solid.
3. Good gibbing, again, it's id software.
4. Interesting style of grabbing the player's attention on where you need to go/points of interest within an area (splashes of purple paint, purple buttons/hand scanners, neon purple lights pointing down pathways,) although this is sometimes not enough and getting lost can be a bit easy.
5. Many of the weapons have alternative fire modes when aimed down sights, as well as different fire modes when used during the super powered rage mode, more of a personal positive, and is not enough to overrule the weapon specific negative 
6. Ability to spawn vehicles (almost) everywhere, excellent game mechanic for player convenience 
7. Gun play is genuinely fun if you use the shotgun and movement properly, so props to them.
8. The Apex engine is a good engine, I respect it and what it can do.
9. Both voice actors for the protagonist, Sam Riegal for the male option, and Amanda C. Miller for the female option, are wonderful voice actors who did quite a good job with their role in the game.

Now for the negatives, these are unfortunately a bit scrambled, I'm not a professional game reviewer, and I ask for your patience and forgiveness in advance.
1. Boring world. The world in Rage 2 is large, it has various environments, however it still feels so grossly empty. A smaller and more densely packed world map would have been wonderful.
2. Tedious driving. The driving mechanic was not well received in the original Rage, and while it is most certainly an upgrade in Rage 2, it's still a hassle with your vehicle getting caught on various parts of the environment or controlling relatively poorly. The flying Icarus vehicle helps incredibly with this, and nearly everyone I've spoken to who has also played this agrees that once they obtained the Icarus they used it almost exclusively. 
3. In a bit of a continuation from point 2, the main vehicle (as I had not tested this extensively with other vehicles, and cannot say) will take massive amounts of damage, sometimes as much as half, when landing off of a jump. This would be less irking to me if there weren't plenty of ramps littered around the map to encourage such a thing.
4. Falling from too great a height will insta-kill you. This sounds obvious, and trust me, it very much so is, but the insta-kill occurs WHILE you are falling, not when you hit the ground. A game that includes a double jump but will not let me jump from the top of a building only to save myself last minute by jumping again in the air and harmless landing on my feet is a game that shouldn't have a double jump at all.
5. This game has an incredible amount of boring "collect-a-thon" ongoing quests. I understand many people love to collect tidbits and interesting bobbles around the map, but the extent Rage 2 has them is a bit ridiculous.
6. Dreadfully annoying SFX for a good handful of things, my prime example being the Authority Recon Droids (yet another collectable) that are hidden throughout the map, the incessant beeping noise they make when nearby is grating to the ears.
7. Sub-par "Played story." As much of the lore/history/npc interaction you can find is hidden within data pads and/or "intel" that's located within the disaster of a menu UI (we'll get there,) the average player will go through a very barebones and considerably average "Hero saves the day" story.
8. The antagonist is incredibly boring. A purely evil genocidal maniac who is, quite literally, more machine than human. I understand sometimes people like to sit back and relax and play a video game that is just, "That person is irredeemably evil, kill em," but I feel as thought Rage 2 would have been the perfect opportunity to create a morally grey villain.
9. Overall, the majority of weapons are boring to use and very situational, the shotgun is almost always the best for every combat encounter. 
10. A far cry (or should I say Just Cause,) styled gameplay loop. The majority of the meat of this game is simply to travel around the map finding locations to kill baddies and complete the same objectives in over and over until you fnially get that next REAL misson (of which there are only less than 10)
11. UI is an absolute disaster within the game's menus/maps, I mean DISASTER. You have to dig through several sub folders to simply get rid of a notification. It's highschooler-hiding-pornography level sometimes with how many folders you have to click through.
12. Rewards for actually completing these three main questlines (I don't even personally think they deserved to be questLINEs, more so quest-handful,) are so insignificant and entirely forgettable. Only one reward is genuinely tangible, and it's a mediocre tank.
13. The Skill, weapon, and "project" upgrade system is overwhelming at the beginning, and tedious by the end. Both skills and weapons require the base to be upgraded with one in game currency, filtrite, while individual perks require an entirely different upgrade module each for skills/weapons. Perks within a skill tree or weapon can also not surpass the base rank. If you want one of the bottom perks of a skill, you need to invest the filtrite to bring the base skill to that level, then spend the modules for the individual perks to get there.
14. Several skills that are dedicated combat skills just aren't reasonably viable due to the speed of combat and damage received on higher difficulties. The lock-on to multiattack wingstick skills, as well as the grenade tennis skills are examples. They put a bottleneck to what is otherwise relatively fun gunplay.

It both can, and WILL, be shredded to pieces by the most basic of enemies on the higher difficulties. So overall, I think the game is really good. I have a few nitpicks, and one glaring issue, that causes the game to be a not recommended. The nitpicks:

1. Upgrading your base stats (hp, damage, and overdrive) gives a measly +5% per upgrade, and the upgrade stuff are expensive and rare, and you need one of each kind to do so. Also, you can only do each upgrade 10 times (so max 150 hp, +50% overdrive and +50% damage). 

2. Trader stocks never restock. Once a particular item runs out, its gone for good. 

3. Defeating a Convoy is way too hard, for the measly reward of 20 auto parts. I fired off 10 heat seeking missiles, 2000 gatling rounds and 400 20mm rounds, to get 20 auto parts and a bit of XP for Loosum. Seriously?

4. For a world based on constantly respawning enemies, why is it that loot never respawns? 

5. World map limits can get nuked to oblivion. Fly towards a destination that is 4000 meters away, and accidentally hit a world edge, 300 meters away? Get reset back to the start and have to fly that 4000 meters again. Limits are not well defined and the moment you enter one, you aren't given a chance to get out.

6. Many of the upgrades for Nanotrites or even Weapons aren't all that great, and thus are a waste of the limited resources available to you. 

7. Loosum Hagar's projects are quite pitiful compared to the other two guys projects. 

8. There are no vehicle upgrades for other unlocked vehicles. You also cannot sell autoparts, which is basically the one item in the game that cannot be sold. Once you fully upgrade the main car, which actually sucks btw (its no Magnum Opus like in Mad Max), you no longer have a use for autoparts. 

9. Weapon Skins are super expensive. I found two skins (maybe there is more variety, not sure), one is $10000 (for reference, you earn like $200-400 from a chest and maybe up to $10 from an enemy kill on a rare chance) and the other is 2500 Mutie Bash tokens (where you might earn 1400 or so in a round taking 10 or so minutes). 

10. I never really felt superhuman, even with all unlocked weapons and nanotrite powers. The only game I ever really felt superhuman in would be Saints Row 4. Feels like a wasted opportunity, honestly. 

Now, the big reason why I won't recommend the game, is because to progress in the story mission, you need to beat a car race. It took me 9 tries to get it; you have to come in 1st place, otherwise it doesn't count. The vehicle handles like ass, there is way too many things you can collide into, and the dirt track makes it easy to spin out. Gating game progress with a car race, is torturous, and I honestly didn't think I would pass it, and told myself that if I didn't get it on the 9th try, I was uninstalling the game. I did beat it, but I wouldn't wish this race on anyone. 

Otherwise, the good (which basically gets drowned out from the bad):
1. Excellent gunplay.
2. Beautiful graphics and ambience.
3. Wide open world.
4. Lots to see, do, and feel you made a difference.
5. Mostly cool Nanotrite abilites, which turn out to be easier to use than I originally thought.
6. Good voice actors.
7. Cars sound cool.

I played about 32 hours of RAGE 2 before taking several doses of an extremely powerful LSD analogue. Through this, I have come to the realization that RAGE 2 is a lazily written, futile, and largely unrewarding experience. While I found RAGE to be highly enjoyable, I find RAGE 2 to be exhausting.

Before I get in to technical issues, I'd like to address mechanics, gameplay, and writing.

[h1]Gameplay and Structure[/h1]
RAGE 2 follows the archetypal open-world shooter design and mechanics, with a little added doom-style turbomurder. The map is divided in to several regions, each anchored by a friendly settlement. Outside the settlement, various points-of-interest exist. At any given point of interest you will perform some combination of fighting, discovering lore, obtaining collectibles, and advancing the plot. Although there exist many locations, they all fall in to some sort of broader category (much as with the far more entertaining Saints Row series). There is little immediate reward for completing these locations, so the process of doing so quickly becomes monotonous - so much so that little to no thought process is required in doing so. This is only compounded by the fact that the vast majority of enemies pose little challenge later in the game, even at the hard difficulty.

The plot itself consists initially of three distinct missions, each belonging to one of three distinct projects. Once these three projects are completed, you may take on the "boss". Completing project objectives rewards project points, which may be spent in any of the three project's skill trees. Side missions do exist; however, the majority of non-story work is comprised of "trade activities". Trade activities more or less entail clearing and/or looting some location. 

Character advancement revolves around the completion of projects and the spending of project points; however, weapons, abilities, and one vehicle (the "main" vehicle) may also be upgraded once unlocked. This presents a somewhat more complicated, if not convoluted, character advancement system. Nonetheless, the trees and upgrades are fairly comprehensive, which makes up for their being fragmented and buried in the UI.

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
As far as mechanics go, RAGE 2 is a pretty solid game. Weapons operate well, and work as intended. With the amount of shooting required; however, ammo reserves tend to run low. Ammo is scattered around the map, but requires some type of interaction in order to collect (either breaking a crate, or interacting with an item). While it is likely the case that this has been done with the intention of encouraging use of all the weapons in the game, there are simply weapons that are not suited to some situations. The addition of 'overdrive' adds an entertaining angle to combat, as you may supercharge your movement, abilities, and weapons.

Vehicle operation is also pretty satisfactory, as one would expect from such a game. Taking corners can be a bit rough at times, although the argument could be made that you are typically driving an absolute whale of a vehicle. You'll also unlock a flying vehicle, which tends to be useful for nearly all activities and will likely see the most use out of any vehicle.

[h1]Writing[/h1]
Much of the writing in the game is lazy, out of place, sophomoric, or any combination of the three. Main character dialog often seems forced, or is outright [i]weird[/i]. Having the character say "another damn crusher nest" or "here's one of them bandit dens again" over and over starts to get repetitive. Multiple lines should have been written, or the lines should have been said, at most, once. Data pads and drone logs are some of the worst offenders, exposing bizarre word choices (such as the french 'alcool' instead of 'alcohol', I'm unsure what inspired this) and poor attempts to use bad grammar (yes, you can fail to intentionally write poorly). Among other strange choices is the name "Goon Squad" (the new name for The Wasted). "Goon Squad" sounds like a store-brand can of bandits, and it occurs to me that little to no inspiration was present when making this decision.

[h1]Technical Issues[/h1]
I will concede that I have been playing this on Linux using WINE (Proton); however, it would appear that many [i]Windows[/i] users are experiencing the same sorts of instability (lots of crashing) with the same frequency that I have. For a 1+ year old game this is inexcusable. There have been many other rough edges, typically gameplay bugs, none of which are worth going over here as they've largely been unobtrusive.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This game is the textbook definition of a mindless shooter. It's something to do for 17.99$ USD or less. Anything more and I wouldn't touch it - quite honestly, I'd suggest holding off until it's even less. Go buy Borderlands 3 instead - it's more entertaining and actually has replay value.
